description: Greetings are highly important in Malaysia and are viewed as an indication of the respect one shows to others.

guidelines.text: Greetings are very important in Malaysia and are thought to indicate the respect you will show an individual from then on.
When greeting a group of people, the oldest person should be greeted first.
Always address individuals using appropriate titles (e.g., Mr, Mrs, Doctor) unless invited to speak more casually.
The common Malay verbal greeting is “Salaam”.
Elders may be addressed as “pakcik” (uncle) or “makcik” (aunty) as a sign of respect.
Handshakes are common across ethnicities; however, physical contact between men and women is often avoided.
When greeting a Malaysian woman, wait for her to extend her hand before offering a handshake.
Some people may place a hand over their chest and nod slightly as a non-contact greeting.
Muslim Malays may greet people of the same gender by grasping the other person’s hands with both hands.
Formal greetings may involve extending both hands to the recipient’s right hand, followed by a slight bow and placing the right hand on the heart.
When greeting someone older, it is respectful to bow the head slightly.
In formal settings, some may touch the forehead or tip of the nose to the back of an elder’s hand.
Older Malaysian Chinese individuals may lower their gaze during greetings as a sign of respect.
